ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FLOODING IN SINGAPORE


    1. Mr Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment (a) how much has been expended so far in making Singapore free from floods; and (b) why has there been flooding whenever there are heavy downpours in spite of this expenditure.

    The Acting Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Swee Say): Sir, ENV spends $60-$70 million a year to improve the drains and canals in Singapore. Since 1984, ENV has spent a total of $1.3 billion on drainage improvement works, including the widening and deepening of main drains and canals to cater for increased storm water runoff arising from new land developments.

Column: 1280



    ENV is committed to reduce flooding in Singapore and has over the years, progressively implemented many drainage improvement projects to alleviate and prevent flooding. This investment in drainage infrastructure has paid off. In spite of rapid urbanisation and intensified redevelopments, the flood situation in Singapore has continued to improve significantly. There are now 238 hectares of flood-prone areas as compared to some 3,200 hectares in the 1970s, a reduction of more than 90%. The floods are less severe and are of relatively short duration.

    Sir, ENV will continue to improve the existing drains and canals to alleviate flooding in flood-prone areas, whenever it is cost-effective to do so. However, it is not feasible to completely rid Singapore of all floods for two reasons.

    Firstly, some of the areas such as those in Boat Quay and Chinatown are low-lying and are barely above high tide level. These premises remain prone to flooding, especially when heavy rain coincides with high tide. The only effective flood control measure is to raise the ground levels of these premises in conjunction with redevelopment plans.

    Secondly, there is a limit to which we can widen drains because of land constraints. Very intense rainfall, which may occur once every five years or so, could overwhelm the capacity of the drains and cause flash floods. Such floods, however, could be minor and of short duration.

    I would like to assure Mr Harun and the House that ENV is committed to press on with our drainage improvement projects to reduce flooding in Singapore, and to keep the flood situation well under control.

    Mr Harun bin A. Ghani (Hong Kah): Sir, I was surprised when the Acting Minister for the Environment mentioned that the Chinatown area is low-lying. I have found out that many hawker centres, for example, the Adam Road hawker centre and some markets are flooded during a

Column: 1281

heavy downpour. Could ENV do something about it?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: I thank Mr Harun for his feedback and I would ask my officials to look into some of these isolated cases.

"CLEAN TOILET CAMPAIGN"


    2. Mr Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment how successful the "Clean Toilet Campaign" has been and what further improvements can be made to ensure clean public toilets.

    The Senior Minister of State for the Environment (Encik Sidek bin Saniff) (for the Acting Minister for the Environment): Sir, our public toilets are cleaner now than they were a few years ago. However, there is still room for improvement.

    Surveys conducted annually, since 1996 when we launched the Clean Toilet Campaign, showed that there have been gradual improvements in the cleanliness of our public toilets.

    Members of the public interviewed during the surveys have given higher scorings consistently over the last five years. Cleaners who maintain these toilets have also consistently rated the toilets to be cleaner over the years. ENV officers participating in the surveys have also independently rated the toilets and have also come up with similar scorings.

    A number of public toilets in ENV and HDB hawker centers have been extensively upgraded and users interviewed have expressed that they are pleased with them. More will be done.

    We will continue to push for clean public toilets in Singapore and will continue to require building managements to keep public toilets in clean and good working condition. Through public education programme, we will continue to remind the public to cooperate and help keep our public toilets clean.

Column: 1282



    Mr Harun bin A. Ghani: Sir, the Senior Minister of State mentioned that surveys were conducted. Could the Senior Minister of State give details about ratings given by ENV for the last five years?

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: Sir, the rating is based on a score of 0-10. On our part, we are very lucky that the scoring happens to be between 6 and 8. This score is given by three parties: ENV officers, cleaners and the users. For instance, in 1996, ENV scored 6.0; cleaners, 6.1; users, 6.8. Recently, we have 8.1 by ENV, 8.0 by cleaners and 8.3 by users. The scoring system maintains that 9.1-10 points is excellent; 8.1-9 points, good; 6.1-8 points, satisfactory; 4.1-6 points, not quite satisfactory; and 4 points and below, poor. We will try our best to do even better.

    Question again proposed.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, in solid waste disposal, recycle,

Column: 1283

reuse and reduction are important issues. Most of the substances and materials that we use for our products are not renewable. We must take action to conserve the resources so that we will leave behind sufficient quantities for the future generations of mankind.

    Recycle, reuse and reduction will be the movement by environment lovers, and responsible world citizens to conserve our resources. From what I read, a BMW car contains a high percentage of materials which could be recycled. You can sell the car to a company for recycling when it is due for scrap. Do we have any policy, setting the constraints in the recycled contents in our new product and the contents of which could be recycled when it is scrapped?

    Sir, the decision for compulsory recycled contents in products has to be commercially viable. However, if nothing is done, the concept of recycling will never take place. At least, we should have some financial incentives or encouragement to include recycled contents, or increasing the recyclability of the products could be made more attractive for the manufacturers' participation. Do we have any incentive schemes to encourage people to work towards this objective? Our Government should show support to the recycle movement by imposing recycled contents in some of their own projects if cost and quality are neutral. One good example is requiring door-frames and wooden floor materials to be made of recycled wood for public housing. In fact, I have seen the product, and no layman can tell the difference.

    We have seen recycled bins in schools and in shopping centres, but we can hardly see any recycled products on sale in the consumer market. Even if there are, like recycled papers, greeting cards and envelopes, they do not seem to be commonly used and acceptable by the people. In fact, recycled products are still fighting a tough battle with normal products. Is there a way that the Government could help to make recycled products more attractive, in terms of pricing and to make known to the

Column: 1284

supporters of the recycle movement? If so, it requires identification of the recycled products, in other words, labelling of recycled products. Are we prepared to consider labelling all recycled products?

    Recycled products could only be viable if the public accepts them. Making people understand the importance of recycling to be an action towards resource conservation and environmental sustainability is the key to the success of recycling. We should have an education programme, teaching and persuading people to feel good about supporting and using recycled products. Would the Government consider launching a Recycle Campaign with the NGOs and schools to increase their awareness in support of the recycle and reuse movement?

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San): Sir, yesterday, the Minister said that at the current rate of solid waste generation and disposal, we would need to build one new incineration plant, occupying about 7 hectares every five years, and one new landfill, the size of Sentosa Island every 25-30 years. He has put forward these statistics to show that this situation is not tenable. He said that his Ministry would look into a solution of closing the solid waste generation loop, ie, to have more recycling. I would like to suggest that he seriously consider another solution, in addition to closing of the loop, that is, the reduction of waste generation.

    To reduce waste generation is very easy to say but the real question is how. In this area, I am afraid that many of the Government's current initiatives are to increase prices to discourage the generation of waste. Is this really effective? Sir, like drugs, the pain of higher prices will become less effective with time and, therefore, more increases are normally needed to overcome the higher threshold of pain. The result is that we may, unwittingly, become a higher and higher cost country and become less competitive.

    Now, with privatisation of solid waste collection, the private collectors will be required to institute waste recycling schemes in public housing and landed properties to reduce generation of solid

Column: 1285

waste. Pushing this problem to the private sector will not resolve the problem at all. All it does is to pass the buck to the private sector on what originally was and still is a national problem. Moreover, if mandated to do so by law, I do not believe that the private sector will do a good and proper job. What may happen would be some activities to satisfy the bare minimum of what the laws require, with the higher cost being passed on to consumers.

    Sir, the Acting Minister has also said that currently, only about 40% of solid waste generated is recycled. Even if the figure can be increased to 50% or 60%, we will soon be reaching the limits of recycling. Therefore, the Government must do more to get Singaporeans to reduce and to reuse products, ie, the 2Rs of what we call the 4Rs of environmental care - reduce, reuse, recycle and recover.
12.45 pm

    Sir, right now, the preferred method in this area of reduction and reuse, as I said earlier, appears to be orientated at the end of the process. That means you charge higher and higher prices for removing garbage, in order to persuade people not to generate so much garbage. As I said earlier, I doubt this will work in the long run. Sir, I like to see the Acting Minister put more emphasis on the beginning of the process, ie, try to educate, encourage and help people to generate less garbage, which is to reduce. And where it is not possible to reduce, then individual households and companies, or those who generate garbage, should be encouraged to reuse.

    Sir, there are a thousand and one ways of doing this, provided the Government is willing to do so. And the money saved in building less incineration plants and landfills could be better used to provide the means for the people to reuse and to reduce. I believe that if we can come out with some form of financial incentive to reward those who generate less garbage, perhaps we will see more success in this area.

Column: 1286



    Furthermore, I think there are many NGOs more than willing to provide ideas and assistance. These are the NGOS in the environmental field. Sir, the other countries have also gone a long way in this direction. We can certainly learn from their experience.

    Mr Kenneth Chen Koon Lap (Hong Kah): Sir, can I take my two cuts together?

    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Kenneth Chen Khoon Lap: Sir, the Minister and several Members have touched on the solid waste problem yesterday and today. But few Singaporeans realise it to be such, because they take it for granted that after the rubbish has been thrown out, it is taken away by a refuse truck and they never see it again. Very few Singaporeans know what actually happens to the refuse after that. As Singapore has a very dense population with very limited land area, refuse disposal is of major concern.

    Although Mr Heng and Prof. Low have already touched on some figures, I would like to go into a bit more details to drive home the point. The amount of waste we produce each day is on the increase. I was informed that in the year 2000, the total tonnage of waste was 7,640 tons per day. The amount of refuse in one year can occupy about 54 football fields. With an increase of 5% per year, it would increase to a staggering 12,500 tons per day within 10 years. The Environment Ministry will have to build one new incineration plant every five years to cope with this. Currently, there are four incineration plants. By the year 2030, we will need 10 incineration plants to dispose of all our daily wastes. All in all, this will require 7 hectares of land and a cost of almost $1 billion.

    But, more seriously, besides allocating more land and financial resources to build more incineration plants, we also need to allocate more landfill space for the ashes and wastes that cannot be burnt. As mentioned by the Minister, at the current rate of waste generation, we will need to allocate landfill space about the size of Sentosa island at the rate of one

Column: 1287

every 30 years. It is certainly a frightening thought.

    I would like to know from the Minister, apart from the four plants he mentioned yesterday, what concerted effort is being taken to address this particular problem. Because, apart from the sheer quantity of waste that we have to handle, we also have to consider the pollution damage caused to our environment. I would like to propose that we should do more to educate the population of the seriousness of the situation. We should consider all measures to reduce the waste generated each day. We must change the mindset of Singaporeans that waste disposal is a problem to be solved by the Environment Ministry alone. But it is not a one dimensional problem. Even if new technologies are found for more efficient methods of waste disposal, as long as we keep on generating waste needlessly, the problem will grow bigger and one day, it may become unsolvable.

    Sir, on a related subject of waste disposal is recycling. We often talk about the importance of recycling, but all the talk never seems to be able to materialise into much action. It is high time we changed our mindset on recycling. Recycling has always been a major issue of environmental consideration, but this environmental consideration has always been overshadowed by the cost consideration. It is often more expensive to recycle something than simply producing it from new materials. This is the reason why recycling has never been able to take off in a big way. However, the most compelling aspect of the environmental consideration is still the necessity to conserve our scarce earth resources. It is not an immediate problem. It is often designated as low priority concern. But with the population growing at a staggering rate each year, very soon most of our resources will be depleted, and we cannot just pass this problem on to our next generation.

    The other equally important consideration is that recycling can be a significant way to lessen our waste disposal problem. I think many Members have already made that clear. It is time for us to rethink some

Column: 1288

of the practices in our daily life. For example, the use of disposable utensils or products made of polystyrene, PVC, plastic or such bio-undegradable materials which cannot be recycled should be minimised. Perhaps we should consider bringing back the old practice of using reusable utensils, even at the expense of having to put up with a little bit more inconvenience. I would suggest the Ministry promote more awareness on the importance of recycling, spread the message that even though it may not be cost effective in the short term, it is essential if we are to preserve our environment and resources and help towards resolving our waste disposal problem.

    Sir, I do not want to go into details of ways and means of re-instituting the various recycling possibilities, because there are so many. But I would like the Minister to promote more recycling initiatives and perhaps introduce some form of incentives to those individuals as well as corporations who take recycling seriously.

    Mr Simon S. C. Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, as I share many of the concerns of the previous speakers, I will try to reduce my points. I share the perception that we have reached a limit to technical solutions. We have built Pulau Semakau, a world's first. We are going to build another incinerator and these are big ticket items in the budget. But beyond solutions, we will need to look at the mindsets and social habits of Singaporeans. Here, I would disagree with Mr Kenneth Chen who spoke just before me. I actually think that the Ministry has done a good job in making citizens generally aware of the problem and aware of the need for recycling. Of course, more can be done for awareness. But the next step we have to take is to move from awareness to action. We have to enable action by making it easy, by allowing enterprise and making our effort effective. What I mean by ease, enterprise and effectiveness goes beyond campaigns or once in a while collecting old phone books or newspapers. We need to have regular projects in each neighbourhood

Column: 1289

or even in each house. We see in many developed countries blue bins or other systems used to collect bottles, cans and other recyclables. I am afraid I cannot understand why we do not have the same. I believe we should.

    The second thing about enterprise connects to the privatisation of waste collection. This is going to be difficult because eventually we are going to have to raise prices. We can, however, do this in a way that is sensitive to the needs of people, because we cannot move house, just because one company charges more than the other to collect our rubbish. In that sense, it is a very imperfect market, even if we privatise. What we can do to make the market better is to create more volume, not just by mandating it. We should create a market. Deposits on cans and bottles are a very small example of the kind of clear incentives we need to create this market, and then create the volume for recycling.

    Sir, more generally, I think there are many other things we can learn from other societies. We are not the first to face this problem, though it is more acute in Singapore. I would like the Minister to share his thoughts with us about closing the loop on waste.

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, I would like to thank the Members for speaking on recycling. As mentioned by Mr Kenneth Chen, waste generation in Singapore is on the increase. Twenty years ago, we produced about 2,500 tons of solid waste every day. Ten years ago, the amount doubled to 5,700 tons and last year, as mentioned by Mr Kenneth Chen, it has gone up by another 35% over the 10 years, to 7,600 tons. The split between the domestic sector and the industrial sector is about 50:50. In other words, every person in Singapore today generates about 0.93 kilogram of solid waste every year. If we were to compare ourselves to, say, USA, it is still lower. In USA, it is 1.97 kilograms; Germany, 1.26 kilograms; Japan, 1.09 kilograms. The good news is that compared to many of the other

Column: 1290

countries, we are still producing less than them. But the bad news is that Singapore, being a small country, faces much greater challenge and constraint - in finding enough space to dispose waste. As mentioned by the Members, every five years, we need to build a new incineration plant. Every 30 years, we need to find a landfill site as big as Sentosa island. Obviously, this is not sustainable.

    Sir, yesterday, I mentioned that in order to achieve sustainability in the disposal of solid waste, we need to accord greater emphasis to waste minimisation. And I thank the Members for speaking up and for their support.

    Yesterday, Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked why do we not focus more on 3Rs - reuse, reduce and recycle. Sir, I agree with him fully. Since 1991, the Ministry of the Environment has been promoting 3Rs very proactively. There are 130 companies in the 3Rs industry, and they deal with a whole host of recycling: wood waste, paper, scrap tyres, copper slabs, marine clay and so on.

    We also promote the fourth R, which is recovery. For example, all our incineration plants today recover heat from incineration of waste, and we feed the electricity to the national grid.

    Yesterday, Prof. Low Seow Chay asked what happens to all these materials collected for recycling. Sir, as I mentioned, the rate of recycling in Singapore today is 40%. Of the wastes that are being collected for recycling, about 50% are recycled in Singapore, and 50% for export. For the 50% recycled in Singapore, waste paper is recycled into paper products such as cardboards, and toilet papers. In the case of wood waste, companies are turning it into chip boards for furniture, wooden panels and so on. We are now using marine clay to make bricks for construction. In fact, HDB will be using some of these bricks produced by one of our recycling companies. So, on the whole, we think that 40% of recycling rate is not bad. If we compare ourselves to the rest of the world, in Germany, Munich city is 42%; Netherlands, 39%. However, the rate of recycling has stabilised at 40%

Column: 1291

since 1996, meaning that since 1996 we have not been able to increase the rate of recycling in Singapore. Therein lies our real challenge.

    Sir, yesterday, Mr Heng Chiang Meng said that we should encourage further recycling. I agree with him because our challenge today is to achieve another breakthrough beyond this 40% recycling rate. Mr Simon Tay mentioned that the privatisation of waste incineration would not solve the problem, in terms of sustainability. I agree with him. We believe that privatisation would only enhance our performance in the short term. But for long-term sustainability, we have to go beyond that. And that is the reason why yesterday, I announced that the ENV has set a target of achieving a 50% recycling rate over the next 10 years. Sir, I must admit that this is not an easy target to achieve. But we think it can be done. It is doable if all of us work harder together to achieve this.
1.00 pm

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked whether the Government is trying to pass the buck to the private sector. I can assure the House that that is not the intention. We look at this challenge as a shared challenge of the three "P" sectors - the Government, the private sector and the people sector. It is a common challenge facing all of us. So we are going to work together. We are not going to pass the buck to the private sector.

    At this moment, the recycling rates for paper, plastic, construction debris and book wastes range from 10% to 60%. We examine each of these items and our assessment is that there is enough scope for all of us to work together to increase the recycling rates for each of these types of wastes by about 20 percentage points over the next 10 years. That is why we believe that the 50% target is doable, not easy but doable, if we work hard enough, if we work together.

    The challenge really is how to extend recycling beyond the industrial sector. The 40% recycling today are basically

Column: 1292

achieved through recycling by the industrial sector. To extend beyond that to the domestic sector and commercial sector, we have to work both the supply and demand sides of recycling.

    Mr Kenneth Chen mentioned that we need to strengthen our education on waste recycling and spread the message, and we have to educate the young. And Mr Simon Tay mentioned that we have to go beyond awareness and turn awareness into action. I agree with both of them. For example, our school children today, at Primary 3, are told about the importance of recycling. My daughter came back from school one day when she was in Primary 3 and asked mummy and daddy, "How can we participate in recycling?" She also asked, "Where is the bin for the plastics and bottles? Where is the bin for the cans?" I was very shy, pretended and said that there was no such system in our home today. The point is that after a few years, my daughter never talks about recycling anymore. Why? The awareness has not been turned into action. There is no continuous reinforcement. As a result, we are not reaping the benefit of all the effort we have put into education. That is the reason why ENV decided that we must now require all the public waste collectors to introduce waste recycling to every household in Singapore so that your daughter, my daughter, your son, my son, after coming home from school, having learned about recycling, hopefully, they will be able to practise recycling on a day-to-day basis.

    Under our contractual agreement with these nine public waste collectors, they are required by ENV to introduce waste recycling schemes and bring recycling to the door-steps of the residents. We believe this will make it easier for each and every household to participate in waste recycling. I am pleased to inform the House that Jurong sector will be the first to launch the scheme by April next month. The other sectors will do so by the end of this year.

    As for recycling at the commercial premises, as mentioned by Mr Simon Tay, I agree with him. In fact, this is another

Column: 1293

challenge that we have to overcome. In the case of the commercial premises, we are going to reach out to the building managements to encourage as many building managements as possible in Singapore to introduce waste recycling in our commercial buildings. Hopefully, over time, we will be able to spread recycling beyond the industrial sector to the domestic and commercial sectors.

    Having taken action on the supply side, we are also taking action on the demand side, meaning that we are going to step up our promotion effort to further develop the recycling industry in Singapore. Our aim is to nurture a vibrant recycling industry in Singapore and position Singapore as a leading centre of excellence in 4Rs (reuse, reduce, recycle and recover) in this region.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng yesterday mentioned that maybe we should introduce more incentives to encourage recycling, and today he mentioned that we ought to do more to promote "reduce" and "reuse".     The situation today is totally different. The Government has successfully implemented its public housing programme to provide affordable housing for Singaporeans. Almost nine in 10 Singaporeans now own their homes. Subsidised rental flats are available for those who still cannot afford home ownership. No family need go without a roof over its head.     On the other hand, rent control is a disincentive for landlords to redevelop or restore their properties.
